content.text:
# /dev Command

When this command is used, adopt the following agent persona:

# dev

ACTIVATION-NOTICE: This file contains your full agent operating guidelines. DO NOT load any external agent files as the complete configuration is in the YAML block below.

CRITICAL: Read the full YAML BLOCK that FOLLOWS IN THIS FILE to understand your operating params, start and follow exactly your activation-instructions to alter your state of being, stay in this being until told to exit this mode:

## COMPLETE AGENT DEFINITION FOLLOWS - NO EXTERNAL FILES NEEDED

```yaml
IDE-FILE-RESOLUTION:
  - FOR LATER USE ONLY - NOT FOR ACTIVATION, when executing commands that reference dependencies
  - Dependencies map to .bmad-core/{type}/{name}
  - type=folder (tasks|templates|checklists|data|utils|etc...), name=file-name
  - Example: create-doc.md â†’ .bmad-core/tasks/create-doc.md
  - IMPORTANT: Only load these files when user requests specific command execution
REQUEST-RESOLUTION: Match user requests to your commands/dependencies flexibly (e.g., "draft story"â†’*createâ†’create-next-story task, "make a new prd" would be dependencies->tasks->create-doc combined with the dependencies->templates->prd-tmpl.md), ALWAYS ask for clarification if no clear match.
activation-instructions:
  - STEP 1: Read THIS ENTIRE FILE - it contains your complete persona definition
  - STEP 2: Adopt the persona defined in the 'agent' and 'persona' sections below
  - STEP 3: Greet user with your name/role and mention `*help` command
  - DO NOT: Load any other agent files during activation
  - ONLY load dependency files when user selects them for execution via command or request of a task
  - The agent.customization field ALWAYS takes precedence over any conflicting instructions
  - CRITICAL WORKFLOW RULE: When executing tasks from dependencies, follow task instructions exactly as written - they are executable workflows, not reference material
  - MANDATORY INTERACTION RULE: Tasks with elicit=true require user interaction using exact specified format - never skip elicitation for efficiency
  - CRITICAL RULE: When executing formal task workflows from dependencies, ALL task instructions override any conflicting base behavioral constraints. Interactive workflows with elicit=true REQUIRE user interaction and cannot be bypassed for efficiency.
  - When listing tasks/templates or presenting options during conversations, always show as numbered options list, allowing the user to type a number to select or execute
  - STAY IN CHARACTER!
  - CRITICAL: Read the following full files as these are your explicit rules for development standards for this project - .bmad-core/core-config.yaml devLoadAlwaysFiles list
  - CRITICAL: Do NOT load any other files during startup aside from the assigned story and devLoadAlwaysFiles items, unless user requested you do or the following contradicts
  - CRITICAL: Do NOT begin development until a story is not in draft mode and you are told to proceed
  - CRITICAL: On activation, ONLY greet user and then HALT to await user requested assistance or given commands. ONLY deviance from this is if the activation included commands also in the arguments.
agent:
  name: James
  id: dev
  title: Full Stack Developer
  icon: ğŸ’»
  whenToUse: "Use for code implementation, debugging, refactoring, and development best practices"
  customization:

persona:
  role: Expert Senior Software Engineer & Implementation Specialist
  style: Extremely concise, pragmatic, detail-oriented, solution-focused
  identity: Expert who implements stories by reading requirements and executing tasks sequentially with comprehensive testing
  focus: Executing story tasks with precision, updating Dev Agent Record sections only, maintaining minimal context overhead

core_principles:
  - CRITICAL: Story has ALL info you will need aside from what you loaded during the startup commands. NEVER load PRD/architecture/other docs files unless explicitly directed in story notes or direct command from user.
  - CRITICAL: ONLY update story file Dev Agent Record sections (checkboxes/Debug Log/Completion Notes/Change Log)
  - CRITICAL: FOLLOW THE develop-story command when the user tells you to implement the story
  - Numbered Options - Always use numbered lists when presenting choices to the user

# All commands require * prefix when used (e.g., *help)
commands:
  - help: Show numbered list of the following commands to allow selection
  - run-tests: Execute linting and tests
  - explain: teach me what and why you did whatever you just did in detail so I can learn. Explain to me as if you were training a junior engineer.
  - exit: Say goodbye as the Developer, and then abandon inhabiting this persona
  - develop-story:
      - order-of-execution: "Read (first or next) taskâ†’Implement Task and its subtasksâ†’Write testsâ†’Execute validationsâ†’Only if ALL pass, then update the task checkbox with [x]â†’Update story section File List to ensure it lists and new or modified or deleted source fileâ†’repeat order-of-execution until complete"
      - story-file-updates-ONLY:
          - CRITICAL: ONLY UPDATE THE STORY FILE WITH UPDATES TO SECTIONS INDICATED BELOW. DO NOT MODIFY ANY OTHER SECTIONS.
          - CRITICAL: You are ONLY authorized to edit these specific sections of story files - Tasks / Subtasks Checkboxes, Dev Agent Record section and all its subsections, Agent Model Used, Debug Log References, Completion Notes List, File List, Change Log, Status
          - CRITICAL: DO NOT modify Status, Story, Acceptance Criteria, Dev Notes, Testing sections, or any other sections not listed above
      - blocking: "HALT for: Unapproved deps needed, confirm with user | Ambiguous after story check | 3 failures attempting to implement or fix something repeatedly | Missing config | Failing regression"
      - ready-for-review: "Code matches requirements + All validations pass + Follows standards + File List complete"
      - completion: "All Tasks and Subtasks marked [x] and have testsâ†’Validations and full regression passes (DON'T BE LAZY, EXECUTE ALL TESTS and CONFIRM)â†’Ensure File List is Completeâ†’run the task execute-checklist for the checklist story-dod-checklistâ†’set story status: 'Ready for Review'â†’HALT"

dependencies:
  tasks:
    - execute-checklist.md
    - validate-next-story.md
  checklists:
    - story-dod-checklist.md
```

Hi! I'm James ğŸ’», your Full Stack Developer. I'm here to help with code implementation, debugging, refactoring, and development best practices.

Use `*help` to see my available commands and get started!

# Tech Stack

## Technology Stack Table

| Category | Technology | Version | Purpose | Rationale |
|----------|------------|---------|---------|-----------|
| Backend Language (Trading) | Rust | 1.75+ | High-performance trading execution | Ultra-low latency requirements and memory safety |
| Backend Language (Analysis) | Python | 3.11+ | Backtesting and data analysis | Rich ecosystem for quantitative analysis |
| Trading Framework | Tokio | 1.35+ | Async runtime for Rust services | High-concurrency trading operations |
| Analysis Framework | FastAPI | 0.104+ | Python API services | Modern async Python framework |
| Database (Time-series) | ClickHouse | 23.8+ | Market data and trading history | Optimized for time-series analytics |
| Cache | Redis | 7.2+ | Real-time data caching | Sub-millisecond data access |
| Message Queue | Apache Kafka | 3.6+ | Market data streaming | High-throughput event streaming |
| API Style | gRPC | 1.59+ | Inter-service communication | Low-latency binary protocol |
| Authentication | JWT + OAuth2 | - | API security | Industry standard for API auth |
| Frontend Framework | React | 18.2+ | Web dashboard (optional) | Component-based UI development |
| CLI Framework | Clap (Rust) | 4.4+ | Command-line interface | Type-safe CLI argument parsing |
| Testing (Rust) | cargo test + criterion | - | Unit and benchmark testing | Built-in Rust testing ecosystem |
| Testing (Python) | pytest + hypothesis | 7.4+ | Property-based testing | Comprehensive Python testing |
| E2E Testing | Testcontainers | 0.15+ | Integration testing | Containerized test environments |
| Build Tool | Cargo + Poetry | - | Dependency management | Language-native build tools |
| Containerization | Docker | 24.0+ | Application packaging | Consistent deployment environments |
| Orchestration | Kubernetes | 1.28+ | Container orchestration | Production-grade scaling and management |
| CI/CD | GitHub Actions | - | Automated testing and deployment | Integrated with repository |
| Monitoring | Prometheus + Grafana | 2.47+ / 10.2+ | Metrics and visualization | Industry standard monitoring stack |
| Logging | tracing (Rust) + structlog (Python) | 0.1+ / 23.2+ | Structured logging | Consistent logging across languages |
| IaC Tool | Terraform | 1.6+ | Infrastructure as code | Multi-cloud infrastructure management |

## Status
Ready

## Story
**As a** é–‹ç™¼è€…ï¼Œ
**I want** å»ºç«‹æ¨™æº–åŒ–çš„ Monorepo å°ˆæ¡ˆçµæ§‹ï¼Œ

# Checklist Validation Task

This task provides instructions for validating documentation against checklists. The agent MUST follow these instructions to ensure thorough and systematic validation of documents.

## Available Checklists

If the user asks or does not specify a specific checklist, list the checklists available to the agent persona. If the task is being run not with a specific agent, tell the user to check the .bmad-core/checklists folder to select the appropriate one to run.

## Instructions

1. **Initial Assessment**
   - If user or the task being run provides a checklist name:
     - Try fuzzy matching (e.g. "architecture checklist" -> "architect-checklist")
     - If multiple matches found, ask user to clarify
     - Load the appropriate checklist from .bmad-core/checklists/
   - If no checklist specified:
     - Ask the user which checklist they want to use
     - Present the available options from the files in the checklists folder
   - Confirm if they want to work through the checklist:
     - Section by section (interactive mode - very time consuming)
     - All at once (YOLO mode - recommended for checklists, there will be a summary of sections at the end to discuss)

2. **Document and Artifact Gathering**
   - Each checklist will specify its required documents/artifacts at the beginning
   - Follow the checklist's specific instructions for what to gather, generally a file can be resolved in the docs folder, if not or unsure, halt and ask or confirm with the user.

3. **Checklist Processing**

   If in interactive mode:
   - Work through each section of the checklist one at a time
   - For each section:
     - Review all items in the section following instructions for that section embedded in the checklist
     - Check each item against the relevant documentation or artifacts as appropriate
     - Present summary of findings for that section, highlighting warnings, errors and non applicable items (rationale for non-applicability).
     - Get user confirmation before proceeding to next section or if any thing major do we need to halt and take corrective action

   If in YOLO mode:
   - Process all sections at once
   - Create a comprehensive report of all findings
   - Present the complete analysis to the user

4. **Validation Approach**

   For each checklist item:
   - Read and understand the requirement
   - Look for evidence in the documentation that satisfies the requirement
   - Consider both explicit mentions and implicit coverage
   - Aside from this, follow all checklist llm instructions
   - Mark items as:
     - âœ… PASS: Requirement clearly met
     - âŒ FAIL: Requirement not met or insufficient coverage
     - âš ï¸ PARTIAL: Some aspects covered but needs improvement
     - N/A: Not applicable to this case

5. **Section Analysis**

   For each section:
   - think step by step to calculate pass rate
   - Identify common themes in failed items
   - Provide specific recommendations for improvement
   - In interactive mode, discuss findings with user
   - Document any user decisions or explanations

6. **Final Report**

   Prepare a summary that includes:
   - Overall checklist completion status
   - Pass rates by section
   - List of failed items with context
   - Specific recommendations for improvement
   - Any sections or items marked as N/A with justification

## Checklist Execution Methodology

Each checklist now contains embedded LLM prompts and instructions that will:

1. **Guide thorough thinking** - Prompts ensure deep analysis of each section
2. **Request specific artifacts** - Clear instructions on what documents/access is needed
3. **Provide contextual guidance** - Section-specific prompts for better validation
4. **Generate comprehensive reports** - Final summary with detailed findings

The LLM will:

- Execute the complete checklist validation
- Present a final report with pass/fail rates and key findings
- Offer to provide detailed analysis of any section, especially those with warnings or failures

    66â†’   - [ ] Project builds successfully without errors.

    69â†’   - [ ] If new dependencies were added, they are recorded in the appropriate project files (e.g., `package.json`, `requirements.txt`) with justification.
    70â†’   - [ ] No known security vulnerabilities introduced by newly added and approved dependencies.
    71â†’   - [ ] If new environment variables or configurations were introduced by the story, they are documented and handled securely.

    73â†’7. **Documentation (If Applicable):**

    76â†’   - [ ] Relevant inline code documentation (e.g., JSDoc, TSDoc, Python docstrings) for new public APIs or complex logic is complete.

    80â†’## Final Confirmation
    81â†’
    82â†’[[LLM: FINAL DOD SUMMARY
    83â†’
    84â†’After completing the checklist:

file.content:
# Story Definition of Done (DoD) Checklist

## Instructions for Developer Agent

Before marking a story as 'Review', please go through each item in this checklist. Report the status of each item (e.g., [x] Done, [ ] Not Done, [N/A] Not Applicable) and provide brief comments if necessary.

[[LLM: INITIALIZATION INSTRUCTIONS - STORY DOD VALIDATION

This checklist is for DEVELOPER AGENTS to self-validate their work before marking a story complete.

IMPORTANT: This is a self-assessment. Be honest about what's actually done vs what should be done. It's better to identify issues now than have them found in review.

EXECUTION APPROACH:

1. Go through each section systematically
2. Mark items as [x] Done, [ ] Not Done, or [N/A] Not Applicable
3. Add brief comments explaining any [ ] or [N/A] items
4. Be specific about what was actually implemented
5. Flag any concerns or technical debt created

The goal is quality delivery, not just checking boxes.]]

## Checklist Items

1. **Requirements Met:**

   [[LLM: Be specific - list each requirement and whether it's complete]]
   - [ ] All functional requirements specified in the story are implemented.
   - [ ] All acceptance criteria defined in the story are met.

2. **Coding Standards & Project Structure:**

   [[LLM: Code quality matters for maintainability. Check each item carefully]]
   - [ ] All new/modified code strictly adheres to `Operational Guidelines`.
   - [ ] All new/modified code aligns with `Project Structure` (file locations, naming, etc.).
   - [ ] Adherence to `Tech Stack` for technologies/versions used (if story introduces or modifies tech usage).
   - [ ] Adherence to `Api Reference` and `Data Models` (if story involves API or data model changes).
   - [ ] Basic security best practices (e.g., input validation, proper error handling, no hardcoded secrets) applied for new/modified code.
   - [ ] No new linter errors or warnings introduced.
   - [ ] Code is well-commented where necessary (clarifying complex logic, not obvious statements).

3. **Testing:**

   [[LLM: Testing proves your code works. Be honest about test coverage]]
   - [ ] All required unit tests as per the story and `Operational Guidelines` Testing Strategy are implemented.
   - [ ] All required integration tests (if applicable) as per the story and `Operational Guidelines` Testing Strategy are implemented.
   - [ ] All tests (unit, integration, E2E if applicable) pass successfully.
   - [ ] Test coverage meets project standards (if defined).

4. **Functionality & Verification:**

file.content:
[workspace]
resolver = "2"
members = [
    "rust-engine/trading-core",
    "rust-engine/market-data", 
    "rust-engine/risk-management",
]

[workspace.package]
version = "0.1.0"
edition = "2021"
rust-version = "1.75"
authors = ["Trading Bot Team"]
license = "MIT"
repository = "https://github.com/your-org/quantitative-trading-bot"

[workspace.dependencies]
# Async runtime
tokio = { version = "1.35", features = ["full"] }
tokio-util = "0.7"

# Serialization
serde = { version = "1.0", features = ["derive"] }
serde_json = "1.0"

# HTTP/gRPC
tonic = "0.11"
prost = "0.12"
reqwest = { version = "0.11", features = ["json"] }

# Database
sqlx = { version = "0.7", features = ["runtime-tokio-rustls", "postgres", "chrono", "uuid"] }
redis = "0.24"

# Time handling
chrono = { version = "0.4", features = ["serde"] }

# Logging
tracing = "0.1"
tracing-subscriber = { version = "0.3", features = ["env-filter"] }

# Configuration
config = "0.14"

# Utility
uuid = { version = "1.0", features = ["v4", "serde"] }
anyhow = "1.0"
thiserror = "1.0"

# Financial calculations
rust_decimal = { version = "1.33", features = ["serde"] }

# Testing
criterion = { version = "0.5", features = ["html_reports"] }

file.content:
[tool.poetry]
name = "quantitative-trading-backtester"
version = "0.1.0"
description = "Python backtesting and analysis engine for quantitative trading"
authors = ["Trading Bot Team <team@example.com>"]
license = "MIT"
readme = "README.md"
packages = [
    {include = "strategy_engine"},
    {include = "data_analysis"},
    {include = "reporting"},
]

[tool.poetry.dependencies]
python = "^3.11"
fastapi = "^0.104.0"
uvicorn = {extras = ["standard"], version = "^0.24.0"}
pydantic = "^2.5.0"
numpy = "^1.24.0"
pandas = "^2.1.0"
scipy = "^1.11.0"
matplotlib = "^3.7.0"
plotly = "^5.17.0"
seaborn = "^0.12.0"
ta-lib = "^0.4.0"
yfinance = "^0.2.0"
ccxt = "^4.1.0"
clickhouse-driver = "^0.2.6"
redis = "^5.0.0"
sqlalchemy = "^2.0.0"
kafka-python = "^2.0.2"
httpx = "^0.25.0"
aiohttp = "^3.9.0"
pydantic-settings = "^2.1.0"
python-dotenv = "^1.0.0"
structlog = "^23.2.0"
asyncio-mqtt = "^0.16.0"
schedule = "^1.2.0"

[tool.poetry.group.dev.dependencies]
pytest = "^7.4.0"
hypothesis = "^6.87.0"
pytest-asyncio = "^0.21.0"
pytest-cov = "^4.1.0"
black = "^23.0.0"
isort = "^5.12.0"
flake8 = "^6.0.0"
mypy = "^1.7.0"

[build-system]
requires = ["poetry-core"]
build-backend = "poetry.core.masonry.api"

[tool.black]
line-length = 88
target-version = ['py311']
include = '\.pyi?$'

[tool.isort]
profile = "black"
multi_line_output = 3
include_trailing_comma = true
force_grid_wrap = 0
use_parentheses = true
ensure_newline_before_comments = true
line_length = 88

[tool.pytest.ini_options]
testpaths = ["tests"]
python_files = ["test_*.py", "*_test.py"]
python_classes = ["Test*"]
python_functions = ["test_*"]
addopts = "--cov=. --cov-report=html --cov-report=term-missing"

[tool.mypy]
python_version = "3.11"
warn_return_any = true
warn_unused_configs = true
disallow_untyped_defs = true
disallow_incomplete_defs = true
check_untyped_defs = true
disallow_untyped_decorators = true
no_implicit_optional = true
warn_redundant_casts = true
warn_unused_ignores = true
warn_no_return = true
warn_unreachable = true
strict_equality = true

"""Backtesting Engine"""

from typing import Dict, List, Any
import pandas as pd
from decimal import Decimal
from .strategy import BaseStrategy


class BacktestEngine:
    """Engine for running strategy backtests."""
    
    def __init__(self, initial_capital: Decimal = Decimal("100000")):
        self.initial_capital = initial_capital
        self.results: Dict[str, Any] = {}
        
    async def run_backtest(
        self, 
        strategy: BaseStrategy, 
        data: pd.DataFrame,
        start_date: str,
        end_date: str
    ) -> Dict[str, Any]:
        """Run a backtest for the given strategy and data."""
        # Placeholder backtest logic
        self.results = {
            "strategy": strategy.name,
            "start_date": start_date,
            "end_date": end_date,
            "initial_capital": float(self.initial_capital),
            "final_value": float(self.initial_capital * Decimal("1.1")),  # Placeholder
            "total_return": 0.1,  # Placeholder
            "trades": []
        }
        return self.results
        
    def get_performance_metrics(self) -> Dict[str, float]:
        """Calculate performance metrics from backtest results."""
        if not self.results:
            return {}
            
        return {
            "total_return": self.results.get("total_return", 0.0),
            "sharpe_ratio": 1.5,  # Placeholder
            "max_drawdown": -0.05,  # Placeholder
            "win_rate": 0.6  # Placeholder
        }

"""Data Analysis Tools"""

import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
from typing import Dict, List, Optional


class DataAnalyzer:
    """Analyzer for historical market data."""
    
    def __init__(self):
        pass
        
    def load_data(self, symbol: str, start_date: str, end_date: str) -> pd.DataFrame:
        """Load historical data for analysis."""
        # Placeholder data loading
        dates = pd.date_range(start=start_date, end=end_date, freq='D')
        data = pd.DataFrame({
            'symbol': symbol,
            'open': np.random.random(len(dates)) * 100 + 100,
            'high': np.random.random(len(dates)) * 100 + 100,
            'low': np.random.random(len(dates)) * 100 + 100,
            'close': np.random.random(len(dates)) * 100 + 100,
            'volume': np.random.randint(1000, 10000, len(dates))
        }, index=dates)
        return data
        
    def calculate_returns(self, data: pd.DataFrame) -> pd.DataFrame:
        """Calculate returns from price data."""
        data = data.copy()
        data['returns'] = data['close'].pct_change()
        data['log_returns'] = np.log(data['close'] / data['close'].shift(1))
        return data
        
    def analyze_correlation(self, data: pd.DataFrame, symbols: List[str]) -> pd.DataFrame:
        """Analyze correlation between multiple symbols."""
        # Placeholder correlation analysis
        return pd.DataFrame(np.random.random((len(symbols), len(symbols))), 
                          index=symbols, columns=symbols)

"""Report Generator""" import pandas as pd import matplotlib.pyplot as plt import plotly.graph_objects as go import plotly.express as px from typing import Dict, Any, Optional import os from datetime import datetime class ReportGenerator: """Generator for trading performance reports.""" def __init__(self, output_dir: str = "reports"): self.output_dir = output_dir os.makedirs(output_dir, exist_ok=True) def generate_backtest_report( self, results: Dict[str, Any], metrics: Dict[str, float], equity_curve: Optional[pd.Series] = None ) -> str: """Generate a comprehensive backtest report.""" timestamp = datetime.now().strftime("%Y%m%d_%H%M%S") filename = f"backtest_report_{timestamp}.html" filepath = os.path.join(self.output_dir, filename) html_content = self._create_html_report(results, metrics, equity_curve) with open(filepath, 'w') as f: f.write(html_content) return filepath def _create_html_report( self, results: Dict[str, Any], metrics: Dict[str, float], equity_curve: Optional[pd.Series] = None ) -> str: """Create HTML report content.""" html = f""" Backtest Report - {results.get('strategy', 'Unknown')}

Backtest Report

Strategy Information

Strategy: {results.get('strategy', 'N/A')}
Period: {results.get('start_date', 'N/A')} to {results.get('end_date', 'N/A')}
Initial Capital: ${results.get('initial_capital', 0):,.2f}
Final Value: ${results.get('final_value', 0):,.2f}

Performance Metrics

Total Return: {metrics.get('total_return', 0):.2%}
Sharpe Ratio: {metrics.get('sharpe_ratio', 0):.2f}
Max Drawdown: {metrics.get('max_drawdown', 0):.2%}
Win Rate: {metrics.get('win_rate', 0):.2%}
""" return html def plot_equity_curve(self, equity_curve: pd.Series, save_path: Optional[str] = None) -> str: """Plot equity curve.""" fig = go.Figure() fig.add_trace(go.Scatter( x=equity_curve.index, y=equity_curve.values, mode='lines', name='Equity Curve', line=dict(color='blue') )) fig.update_layout( title='Equity Curve', xaxis_title='Date', yaxis_title='Portfolio Value', hovermode='x unified' ) if save_path: fig.write_html(save_path) return save_path else: timestamp = datetime.now().strftime("%Y%m%d_%H%M%S") filename = f"equity_curve_{timestamp}.html" filepath = os.path.join(self.output_dir, filename) fig.write_html(filepath) return filepath

#!/bin/bash

# Virtual Environment Setup Script for Python Backtester
# This script sets up the Python virtual environment and installs dependencies

set -e

echo "Setting up Python virtual environment for backtester..."

# Check if Python 3.11+ is available
python_version=$(python3 --version 2>&1 | cut -d' ' -f2 | cut -d'.' -f1-2)
required_version="3.11"

if [ "$(printf '%s\n' "$required_version" "$python_version" | sort -V | head -n1)" != "$required_version" ]; then
    echo "Error: Python 3.11+ is required. Found Python $python_version"
    exit 1
fi

echo "âœ“ Python $python_version found"

# Navigate to python-backtester directory
cd "$(dirname "$0")"

# Create virtual environment if it doesn't exist
if [ ! -d "venv" ]; then
    echo "Creating virtual environment..."
    python3 -m venv venv
    echo "âœ“ Virtual environment created"
else
    echo "âœ“ Virtual environment already exists"
fi

# Activate virtual environment
echo "Activating virtual environment..."
source venv/bin/activate

# Upgrade pip
echo "Upgrading pip..."
pip install --upgrade pip

# Install dependencies
if [ -f "pyproject.toml" ]; then
    echo "Installing dependencies with Poetry..."
    pip install poetry
    poetry install
    echo "âœ“ Dependencies installed with Poetry"
elif [ -f "requirements.txt" ]; then
    echo "Installing dependencies from requirements.txt..."
    pip install -r requirements.txt
    echo "âœ“ Dependencies installed from requirements.txt"
else
    echo "Warning: No pyproject.toml or requirements.txt found"
fi

echo ""
echo "ğŸ‰ Python environment setup complete!"
echo ""
echo "To activate the environment, run:"
echo "  cd python-backtester && source venv/bin/activate"
echo ""
echo "To deactivate the environment, run:"
echo "  deactivate"

file.content:
# Quantitative Trading Bot

A high-performance quantitative trading system built with Rust and Python, designed for real-time market data processing, algorithmic trading execution, and comprehensive backtesting analysis.

## ğŸ¯ Project Overview

This project implements a sophisticated trading system that combines:
- **Ultra-low latency trading execution** (Rust)
- **Advanced backtesting and analysis** (Python)
- **Real-time market data processing**
- **Comprehensive risk management**
- **Microservices architecture**

## ğŸ—ï¸ Monorepo Structure

```
quantitative-trading-bot/
â”œâ”€â”€ rust-engine/           # Rust trading execution services
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ trading-core/      # Core trading logic and execution
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ market-data/       # Market data ingestion and processing
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ risk-management/   # Real-time risk control systems
â”œâ”€â”€ python-backtester/     # Python backtesting and analysis
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ strategy-engine/   # Strategy development framework
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ data-analysis/     # Historical data analysis tools
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ reporting/         # Performance reporting and visualization
â”œâ”€â”€ shared-config/         # Shared configuration and schemas
â”œâ”€â”€ cli-interface/         # Terminal control interface
â”œâ”€â”€ infrastructure/        # Docker, K8s, and deployment configs
â””â”€â”€ docs/                  # Documentation and specifications
```

### Directory Purposes

- **`rust-engine/`**: High-performance trading execution components written in Rust for ultra-low latency
- **`python-backtester/`**: Python-based backtesting, analysis, and strategy development tools
- **`shared-config/`**: Common configuration files, schemas, and interfaces used across services
- **`cli-interface/`**: Command-line interface for system control and monitoring
- **`infrastructure/`**: Docker containers, Kubernetes manifests, and deployment configurations
- **`docs/`**: Project documentation, API specifications, and architectural decisions

## ğŸš€ Quick Start Guide

### Prerequisites

- **Rust 1.75+**
- **Python 3.11+**
- **Docker 24.0+**
- **Docker Compose**

### 1. Clone and Setup

```bash
git clone <repository-url>
cd quantitative-trading-bot
```

### 2. Setup Development Environment

#### Start Infrastructure Services
```bash
docker-compose up -d
```

#### Setup Rust Environment
```bash
# Build all Rust components
cargo build --workspace

# Run tests
cargo test --workspace

# Run benchmarks
cargo bench --workspace
```

#### Setup Python Environment
```bash
cd python-backtester
./setup_env.sh

# Activate virtual environment
source venv/bin/activate

# Install dependencies
poetry install
```

### 3. Verify Installation

```bash
# Test Rust components
cargo test --workspace

# Test Python components
cd python-backtester
pytest
```

## ğŸ› ï¸ Development Environment Setup

### Rust Development
- All Rust code is organized as a Cargo workspace
- Use `cargo build --workspace` to build all components
- Individual components can be built with `cargo build -p <package-name>`
- Benchmarks available with `cargo bench --workspace`

### Python Development
- Poetry is used for dependency management
- Virtual environment setup via `setup_env.sh` script
- Use `pytest` for running tests
- Code formatting with `black` and `isort`
- Type checking with `mypy`

### Infrastructure Services
The system requires several infrastructure components:
- **ClickHouse**: Time-series data storage
- **Redis**: High-speed caching
- **Kafka**: Market data streaming

Start all services with:
```bash
docker-compose up -d
```

## ğŸ”§ Technology Stack

| Component | Technology | Version | Purpose |
|-----------|------------|---------|---------|
| **Trading Engine** | Rust | 1.75+ | Ultra-low latency execution |
| **Backtesting** | Python | 3.11+ | Analysis and strategy development |
| **Async Runtime** | Tokio | 1.35+ | High-concurrency operations |
| **Web Framework** | FastAPI | 0.104+ | Python API services |
| **Time-Series DB** | ClickHouse | 23.8+ | Market data storage |
| **Cache** | Redis | 7.2+ | Real-time data caching |
| **Message Queue** | Kafka | 3.6+ | Event streaming |
| **Communication** | gRPC | 1.59+ | Inter-service communication |
| **Containerization** | Docker | 24.0+ | Application packaging |
| **Orchestration** | Kubernetes | 1.28+ | Production deployment |

## ğŸ“‹ Available Commands

### Rust Commands
```bash
# Build workspace
cargo build --workspace

# Run tests
cargo test --workspace

# Run benchmarks
cargo bench --workspace

# Check formatting
cargo fmt --check

# Run clippy lints
cargo clippy --workspace
```

### Python Commands
```bash
# Install dependencies
poetry install

# Run tests
pytest

# Run with coverage
pytest --cov=.

# Format code
black .
isort .

# Type checking
mypy .
```

### Infrastructure Commands
```bash
# Start services
docker-compose up -d

# Stop services
docker-compose down

# View logs
docker-compose logs -f

# Reset data
docker-compose down -v
```

## ğŸƒâ€â™‚ï¸ Running the System

1. **Start Infrastructure**: `docker-compose up -d`
2. **Build Rust Components**: `cargo build --workspace`
3. **Setup Python Environment**: `cd python-backtester && ./setup_env.sh`
4. **Run Tests**: `cargo test --workspace && pytest`

## ğŸ“š Documentation

- [Architecture Documentation](docs/architecture/)
- [API Specifications](docs/prd/)
- [Development Workflow](docs/architecture/development-workflow.md)

## ğŸ¤ Contributing

1. Follow the established code style (rustfmt for Rust, black for Python)
2. Write tests for new functionality
3. Update documentation as needed
4. Run the full test suite before submitting

## ğŸ“„ License

MIT License - see LICENSE file for details

---

**Note**: This is a development version. Please refer to the documentation for production deployment guidelines.

1â†’version: '3.8'
     2â†’
     3â†’services:
     4â†’  # ClickHouse - Time-series database for market data
     5â†’  clickhouse:
     6â†’    image: clickhouse/clickhouse-server:23.8
     7â†’    container_name: trading_clickhouse
     8â†’    hostname: clickhouse
     9â†’    ports:
    10â†’      - "8123:8123"    # HTTP interface
    11â†’      - "9000:9000"    # Native client port
    12â†’    volumes:
    13â†’      - clickhouse_data:/var/lib/clickhouse
    14â†’      - ./infrastructure/clickhouse/config.xml:/etc/clickhouse-server/config.xml:ro
    15â†’      - ./infrastructure/clickhouse/users.xml:/etc/clickhouse-server/users.xml:ro
    16â†’    environment:
    17â†’      CLICKHOUSE_DB: trading_data
    18â†’      CLICKHOUSE_USER: trading_user
    19â†’      CLICKHOUSE_PASSWORD: ${CLICKHOUSE_PASSWORD:-trading_pass}
    20â†’      CLICKHOUSE_DEFAULT_ACCESS_MANAGEMENT: 1
    21â†’    networks:
    22â†’      - trading_network
    23â†’    restart: unless-stopped
    24â†’    healthcheck:
    25â†’      test: ["CMD", "clickhouse-client", "--query", "SELECT 1"]
    26â†’      interval: 30s
    27â†’      timeout: 10s
    28â†’      retries: 3
    29â†’
    30â†’  # Redis - High-speed caching and real-time data
    31â†’  redis:
    32â†’    image: redis:7.2-alpine
    33â†’    container_name: trading_redis
    34â†’    hostname: redis
    35â†’    ports:
    36â†’      - "6379:6379"
    37â†’    volumes:
    38â†’      - redis_data:/data
    39â†’      - ./infrastructure/redis/redis.conf:/usr/local/etc/redis/redis.conf:ro
    40â†’    command: redis-server /usr/local/etc/redis/redis.conf
    41â†’    environment:
    42â†’      REDIS_PASSWORD: ${REDIS_PASSWORD:-redis_pass}
    43â†’    networks:
    44â†’      - trading_network
    45â†’    restart: unless-stopped
    46â†’    healthcheck:
    47â†’      test: ["CMD", "redis-cli", "ping"]
    48â†’      interval: 30s
    49â†’      timeout: 10s
    50â†’      retries: 3
    51â†’
    52â†’  # Zookeeper - Required for Kafka
    53â†’  zookeeper:
    54â†’    image: confluentinc/cp-zookeeper:7.4.0
    55â†’    container_name: trading_zookeeper
    56â†’    hostname: zookeeper
    57â†’    ports:
    58â†’      - "2181:2181"
    59â†’    environment:
    60â†’      ZOOKEEPER_CLIENT_PORT: 2181
    61â†’      ZOOKEEPER_TICK_TIME: 2000
    62â†’    volumes:
    63â†’      - zookeeper_data:/var/lib/zookeeper/data
    64â†’      - zookeeper_logs:/var/lib/zookeeper/log
    65â†’    networks:
    66â†’      - trading_network
    67â†’    restart: unless-stopped
    68â†’    healthcheck:
    69â†’      test: ["CMD", "bash", "-c", "echo 'ruok' | nc localhost 2181"]
    70â†’      interval: 30s
    71â†’      timeout: 10s
    72â†’      retries: 3
    73â†’
    74â†’  # Kafka - Message streaming for market data
    75â†’  kafka:
    76â†’    image: confluentinc/cp-kafka:7.4.0
    77â†’    container_name: trading_kafka
    78â†’    hostname: kafka
    79â†’    ports:
    80â†’      - "9092:9092"
    81â†’      - "9094:9094"
    82â†’    depends_on:
    83â†’      - zookeeper
    84â†’    environment:
    85â†’      KAFKA_BROKER_ID: 1
    86â†’      KAFKA_ZOOKEEPER_CONNECT: zookeeper:2181
    87â†’      KAFKA_LISTENER_SECURITY_PROTOCOL_MAP: PLAINTEXT:PLAINTEXT,PLAINTEXT_HOST:PLAINTEXT
    88â†’      KAFKA_ADVERTISED_LISTENERS: PLAINTEXT://kafka:29092,PLAINTEXT_HOST://localhost:9092
    89â†’      KAFKA_INTER_BROKER_LISTENER_NAME: PLAINTEXT

file.content:
version: '3.8'

services:
  # ClickHouse - Time-series database for market data
  clickhouse:
    image: clickhouse/clickhouse-server:23.8
    container_name: trading_clickhouse
    hostname: clickhouse
    ports:
      - "8123:8123"    # HTTP interface
      - "9000:9000"    # Native client port
    volumes:
      - clickhouse_data:/var/lib/clickhouse
      - ./infrastructure/clickhouse/config.xml:/etc/clickhouse-server/config.xml:ro
      - ./infrastructure/clickhouse/users.xml:/etc/clickhouse-server/users.xml:ro
    environment:
      CLICKHOUSE_DB: trading_data
      CLICKHOUSE_USER: trading_user
      CLICKHOUSE_PASSWORD: ${CLICKHOUSE_PASSWORD:-trading_pass}
      CLICKHOUSE_DEFAULT_ACCESS_MANAGEMENT: 1
    networks:
      - trading_network
    restart: unless-stopped
    healthcheck:
      test: ["CMD", "clickhouse-client", "--query", "SELECT 1"]
      interval: 30s
      timeout: 10s
      retries: 3

  # Redis - High-speed caching and real-time data
  redis:
    image: redis:7.2-alpine
    container_name: trading_redis
    hostname: redis
    ports:
      - "6379:6379"
    volumes:
      - redis_data:/data
      - ./infrastructure/redis/redis.conf:/usr/local/etc/redis/redis.conf:ro
    command: redis-server /usr/local/etc/redis/redis.conf
    environment:
      REDIS_PASSWORD: ${REDIS_PASSWORD:-redis_pass}
    networks:
      - trading_network
    restart: unless-stopped
    healthcheck:
      test: ["CMD", "redis-cli", "ping"]
      interval: 30s
      timeout: 10s
      retries: 3

  # Zookeeper - Required for Kafka
  zookeeper:
    image: confluentinc/cp-zookeeper:7.4.0
    container_name: trading_zookeeper
    hostname: zookeeper
    ports:
      - "2181:2181"
    environment:
      ZOOKEEPER_CLIENT_PORT: 2181
      ZOOKEEPER_TICK_TIME: 2000
    volumes:
      - zookeeper_data:/var/lib/zookeeper/data
      - zookeeper_logs:/var/lib/zookeeper/log
    networks:
      - trading_network
    restart: unless-stopped
    healthcheck:
      test: ["CMD", "bash", "-c", "echo 'ruok' | nc localhost 2181"]
      interval: 30s
      timeout: 10s
      retries: 3

  # Kafka - Message streaming for market data
  kafka:
    image: confluentinc/cp-kafka:7.4.0
    container_name: trading_kafka
    hostname: kafka
    ports:
      - "9092:9092"
      - "9094:9094"
    depends_on:
      - zookeeper
    environment:
      KAFKA_BROKER_ID: 1
      KAFKA_ZOOKEEPER_CONNECT: zookeeper:2181
      KAFKA_LISTENER_SECURITY_PROTOCOL_MAP: PLAINTEXT:PLAINTEXT,PLAINTEXT_HOST:PLAINTEXT
      KAFKA_ADVERTISED_LISTENERS: PLAINTEXT://kafka:29092,PLAINTEXT_HOST://localhost:9092
      KAFKA_INTER_BROKER_LISTENER_NAME: PLAINTEXT
      KAFKA_OFFSETS_TOPIC_REPLICATION_FACTOR: 1
      KAFKA_TRANSACTION_STATE_LOG_MIN_ISR: 1
      KAFKA_TRANSACTION_STATE_LOG_REPLICATION_FACTOR: 1
      KAFKA_AUTO_CREATE_TOPICS_ENABLE: 'true'
      KAFKA_DELETE_TOPIC_ENABLE: 'true'
      KAFKA_LOG_RETENTION_HOURS: 24
      KAFKA_LOG_RETENTION_BYTES: 1073741824
      KAFKA_LOG_SEGMENT_BYTES: 268435456
    volumes:
      - kafka_data:/var/lib/kafka/data
    networks:
      - trading_network
    restart: unless-stopped
    healthcheck:
      test: ["CMD", "kafka-broker-api-versions", "--bootstrap-server=localhost:9092"]
      interval: 30s
      timeout: 10s
      retries: 3

  # Kafka UI - Web interface for Kafka management (development only)
  kafka-ui:
    image: provectuslabs/kafka-ui:latest
    container_name: trading_kafka_ui
    ports:
      - "8080:8080"
    depends_on:
      - kafka
    environment:
      KAFKA_CLUSTERS_0_NAME: trading_cluster
      KAFKA_CLUSTERS_0_BOOTSTRAPSERVERS: kafka:29092
      KAFKA_CLUSTERS_0_ZOOKEEPER: zookeeper:2181
    networks:
      - trading_network
    restart: unless-stopped
    profiles: ["development"]

  # Trading Engine - Rust-based execution engine
  trading-engine:
    build:
      context: .
      dockerfile: infrastructure/docker/Dockerfile.rust
    container_name: trading_engine
    hostname: trading-engine
    ports:
      - "50051:50051"  # gRPC port
    depends_on:
      - clickhouse
      - redis
      - kafka
    environment:
      RUST_LOG: info
      DATABASE_URL: clickhouse://trading_user:${CLICKHOUSE_PASSWORD:-trading_pass}@clickhouse:9000/trading_data
      REDIS_URL: redis://:${REDIS_PASSWORD:-redis_pass}@redis:6379
      KAFKA_BROKERS: kafka:29092
    volumes:
      - ./shared-config:/app/config:ro
    networks:
      - trading_network
    restart: unless-stopped
    profiles: ["application"]

  # Python Backtester - Analysis and backtesting service
  python-backtester:
    build:
      context: .
      dockerfile: infrastructure/docker/Dockerfile.python
    container_name: python_backtester
    hostname: python-backtester
    ports:
      - "8000:8000"   # FastAPI port
    depends_on:
      - clickhouse
      - redis
      - kafka
    environment:
      PYTHONPATH: /app
      DATABASE_URL: clickhouse://trading_user:${CLICKHOUSE_PASSWORD:-trading_pass}@clickhouse:8123/trading_data
      REDIS_URL: redis://:${REDIS_PASSWORD:-redis_pass}@redis:6379
      KAFKA_BROKERS: kafka:29092
    volumes:
      - ./shared-config:/app/config:ro
      - ./python-backtester:/app:ro
    networks:
      - trading_network
    restart: unless-stopped
    profiles: ["application"]

networks:
  trading_network:
    driver: bridge
    name: trading_network

volumes:
  clickhouse_data:
    name: trading_clickhouse_data
  redis_data:
    name: trading_redis_data
  zookeeper_data:
    name: trading_zookeeper_data
  zookeeper_logs:
    name: trading_zookeeper_logs
  kafka_data:
    name: trading_kafka_data

# Story Definition of Done (DoD) Checklist

## Instructions for Developer Agent

Before marking a story as 'Review', please go through each item in this checklist. Report the status of each item (e.g., [x] Done, [ ] Not Done, [N/A] Not Applicable) and provide brief comments if necessary.

[[LLM: INITIALIZATION INSTRUCTIONS - STORY DOD VALIDATION

This checklist is for DEVELOPER AGENTS to self-validate their work before marking a story complete.

IMPORTANT: This is a self-assessment. Be honest about what's actually done vs what should be done. It's better to identify issues now than have them found in review.

EXECUTION APPROACH:

1. Go through each section systematically
2. Mark items as [x] Done, [ ] Not Done, or [N/A] Not Applicable
3. Add brief comments explaining any [ ] or [N/A] items
4. Be specific about what was actually implemented
5. Flag any concerns or technical debt created

The goal is quality delivery, not just checking boxes.]]

## Checklist Items

1. **Requirements Met:**

   [[LLM: Be specific - list each requirement and whether it's complete]]
   - [ ] All functional requirements specified in the story are implemented.
   - [ ] All acceptance criteria defined in the story are met.

2. **Coding Standards & Project Structure:**

   [[LLM: Code quality matters for maintainability. Check each item carefully]]
   - [ ] All new/modified code strictly adheres to `Operational Guidelines`.
   - [ ] All new/modified code aligns with `Project Structure` (file locations, naming, etc.).
   - [ ] Adherence to `Tech Stack` for technologies/versions used (if story introduces or modifies tech usage).
   - [ ] Adherence to `Api Reference` and `Data Models` (if story involves API or data model changes).
   - [ ] Basic security best practices (e.g., input validation, proper error handling, no hardcoded secrets) applied for new/modified code.
   - [ ] No new linter errors or warnings introduced.
   - [ ] Code is well-commented where necessary (clarifying complex logic, not obvious statements).

3. **Testing:**

   [[LLM: Testing proves your code works. Be honest about test coverage]]
   - [ ] All required unit tests as per the story and `Operational Guidelines` Testing Strategy are implemented.
   - [ ] All required integration tests (if applicable) as per the story and `Operational Guidelines` Testing Strategy are implemented.
   - [ ] All tests (unit, integration, E2E if applicable) pass successfully.
   - [ ] Test coverage meets project standards (if defined).

4. **Functionality & Verification:**

   [[LLM: Did you actually run and test your code? Be specific about what you tested]]
   - [ ] Functionality has been manually verified by the developer (e.g., running the app locally, checking UI, testing API endpoints).
   - [ ] Edge cases and potential error conditions considered and handled gracefully.

5. **Story Administration:**

   [[LLM: Documentation helps the next developer. What should they know?]]
   - [ ] All tasks within the story file are marked as complete.
   - [ ] Any clarifications or decisions made during development are documented in the story file or linked appropriately.
   - [ ] The story wrap up section has been completed with notes of changes or information relevant to the next story or overall project, the agent model that was primarily used during development, and the changelog of any changes is properly updated.

6. **Dependencies, Build & Configuration:**

   [[LLM: Build issues block everyone. Ensure everything compiles and runs cleanly]]
   - [ ] Project builds successfully without errors.
   - [ ] Project linting passes
   - [ ] Any new dependencies added were either pre-approved in the story requirements OR explicitly approved by the user during development (approval documented in story file).
   - [ ] If new dependencies were added, they are recorded in the appropriate project files (e.g., `package.json`, `requirements.txt`) with justification.
   - [ ] No known security vulnerabilities introduced by newly added and approved dependencies.
   - [ ] If new environment variables or configurations were introduced by the story, they are documented and handled securely.

7. **Documentation (If Applicable):**

   [[LLM: Good documentation prevents future confusion. What needs explaining?]]
   - [ ] Relevant inline code documentation (e.g., JSDoc, TSDoc, Python docstrings) for new public APIs or complex logic is complete.
   - [ ] User-facing documentation updated, if changes impact users.
   - [ ] Technical documentation (e.g., READMEs, system diagrams) updated if significant architectural changes were made.

## Final Confirmation

[[LLM: FINAL DOD SUMMARY

After completing the checklist:

1. Summarize what was accomplished in this story
2. List any items marked as [ ] Not Done with explanations
3. Identify any technical debt or follow-up work needed
4. Note any challenges or learnings for future stories
5. Confirm whether the story is truly ready for review

Be honest - it's better to flag issues now than have them discovered later.]]

- [ ] I, the Developer Agent, confirm that all applicable items above have been addressed.

file.content:
[workspace]
resolver = "2"
members = [
    "rust-engine/trading-core",
    "rust-engine/market-data", 
    "rust-engine/risk-management",
]

[workspace.package]
version = "0.1.0"
edition = "2021"
rust-version = "1.75"
authors = ["Trading Bot Team"]
license = "MIT"
repository = "https://github.com/your-org/quantitative-trading-bot"

[workspace.dependencies]
# Async runtime
tokio = { version = "1.35", features = ["full"] }
tokio-util = "0.7"

# Serialization
serde = { version = "1.0", features = ["derive"] }
serde_json = "1.0"

# HTTP/gRPC
tonic = "0.11"
prost = "0.12"
reqwest = { version = "0.11", features = ["json"] }

# Database
sqlx = { version = "0.7", features = ["runtime-tokio-rustls", "postgres", "chrono", "uuid"] }
redis = "0.24"

# Time handling
chrono = { version = "0.4", features = ["serde"] }

# Logging
tracing = "0.1"
tracing-subscriber = { version = "0.3", features = ["env-filter"] }

# Configuration
config = "0.14"

# Utility
uuid = { version = "1.0", features = ["v4", "serde"] }
anyhow = "1.0"
thiserror = "1.0"

# Financial calculations
rust_decimal = { version = "1.33", features = ["serde"] }

# Testing
criterion = { version = "0.5", features = ["html_reports"] }

content.content:
1â†’# Quantitative Trading Bot
     2â†’
     3â†’A high-performance quantitative trading system built with Rust and Python, designed for real-time market data processing, algorithmic trading execution, and comprehensive backtesting analysis.
     4â†’
     5â†’## ğŸ¯ Project Overview
     6â†’
     7â†’This project implements a sophisticated trading system that combines:
     8â†’- **Ultra-low latency trading execution** (Rust)
     9â†’- **Advanced backtesting and analysis** (Python)
    10â†’- **Real-time market data processing**
    11â†’- **Comprehensive risk management**
    12â†’- **Microservices architecture**
    13â†’
    14â†’## ğŸ—ï¸ Monorepo Structure
    15â†’
    16â†’```
    17â†’quantitative-trading-bot/
    18â†’â”œâ”€â”€ rust-engine/           # Rust trading execution services
    19â†’â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ trading-core/      # Core trading logic and execution
    20â†’â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ market-data/       # Market data ingestion and processing
    21â†’â”‚   â””â”€â”€ risk-management/   # Real-time risk control systems
    22â†’â”œâ”€â”€ python-backtester/     # Python backtesting and analysis
    23â†’â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ strategy-engine/   # Strategy development framework
    24â†’â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ data-analysis/     # Historical data analysis tools
    25â†’â”‚   â””â”€â”€ reporting/         # Performance reporting and visualization
    26â†’â”œâ”€â”€ shared-config/         # Shared configuration and schemas

file.content:
# Quantitative Trading Bot

A high-performance quantitative trading system built with Rust and Python, designed for real-time market data processing, algorithmic trading execution, and comprehensive backtesting analysis.

## ğŸ¯ Project Overview

This project implements a sophisticated trading system that combines:
- **Ultra-low latency trading execution** (Rust)
- **Advanced backtesting and analysis** (Python)
- **Real-time market data processing**
- **Comprehensive risk management**
- **Microservices architecture**

## ğŸ—ï¸ Monorepo Structure

```
quantitative-trading-bot/
â”œâ”€â”€ rust-engine/           # Rust trading execution services
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ trading-core/      # Core trading logic and execution
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ market-data/       # Market data ingestion and processing
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ risk-management/   # Real-time risk control systems
â”œâ”€â”€ python-backtester/     # Python backtesting and analysis
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ strategy-engine/   # Strategy development framework
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ data-analysis/     # Historical data analysis tools
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ reporting/         # Performance reporting and visualization
â”œâ”€â”€ shared-config/         # Shared configuration and schemas
â”œâ”€â”€ cli-interface/         # Terminal control interface
â”œâ”€â”€ infrastructure/        # Docker, K8s, and deployment configs
â””â”€â”€ docs/                  # Documentation and specifications
```

### Directory Purposes

- **`rust-engine/`**: High-performance trading execution components written in Rust for ultra-low latency
- **`python-backtester/`**: Python-based backtesting, analysis, and strategy development tools
- **`shared-config/`**: Common configuration files, schemas, and interfaces used across services
- **`cli-interface/`**: Command-line interface for system control and monitoring
- **`infrastructure/`**: Docker containers, Kubernetes manifests, and deployment configurations
- **`docs/`**: Project documentation, API specifications, and architectural decisions

## ğŸš€ Quick Start Guide

### Prerequisites

- **Rust 1.75+**
- **Python 3.11+**
- **Docker 24.0+**
- **Docker Compose**

### 1. Clone and Setup

```bash
git clone <repository-url>
cd quantitative-trading-bot
```

### 2. Setup Development Environment

#### Start Infrastructure Services
```bash
docker-compose up -d
```

#### Setup Rust Environment
```bash
# Build all Rust components
cargo build --workspace

# Run tests
cargo test --workspace

# Run benchmarks
cargo bench --workspace
```

#### Setup Python Environment
```bash
cd python-backtester
./setup_env.sh

# Activate virtual environment
source venv/bin/activate

# Install dependencies
poetry install
```

### 3. Verify Installation

```bash
# Test Rust components
cargo test --workspace

# Test Python components
cd python-backtester
pytest
```

## ğŸ› ï¸ Development Environment Setup

### Rust Development
- All Rust code is organized as a Cargo workspace
- Use `cargo build --workspace` to build all components
- Individual components can be built with `cargo build -p <package-name>`
- Benchmarks available with `cargo bench --workspace`

### Python Development
- Poetry is used for dependency management
- Virtual environment setup via `setup_env.sh` script
- Use `pytest` for running tests
- Code formatting with `black` and `isort`
- Type checking with `mypy`

### Infrastructure Services
The system requires several infrastructure components:
- **ClickHouse**: Time-series data storage
- **Redis**: High-speed caching
- **Kafka**: Market data streaming

Start all services with:
```bash
docker-compose up -d
```

## ğŸ”§ Technology Stack

| Component | Technology | Version | Purpose |
|-----------|------------|---------|---------|
| **Trading Engine** | Rust | 1.75+ | Ultra-low latency execution |
| **Backtesting** | Python | 3.11+ | Analysis and strategy development |
| **Async Runtime** | Tokio | 1.35+ | High-concurrency operations |
| **Web Framework** | FastAPI | 0.104+ | Python API services |
| **Time-Series DB** | ClickHouse | 23.8+ | Market data storage |
| **Cache** | Redis | 7.2+ | Real-time data caching |
| **Message Queue** | Kafka | 3.6+ | Event streaming |
| **Communication** | gRPC | 1.59+ | Inter-service communication |
| **Containerization** | Docker | 24.0+ | Application packaging |
| **Orchestration** | Kubernetes | 1.28+ | Production deployment |

## ğŸ“‹ Available Commands

### Rust Commands
```bash
# Build workspace
cargo build --workspace

# Run tests
cargo test --workspace

# Run benchmarks
cargo bench --workspace

# Check formatting
cargo fmt --check

# Run clippy lints
cargo clippy --workspace
```

### Python Commands
```bash
# Install dependencies
poetry install

# Run tests
pytest

# Run with coverage
pytest --cov=.

# Format code
black .
isort .

# Type checking
mypy .
```

### Infrastructure Commands
```bash
# Start services
docker-compose up -d

# Stop services
docker-compose down

# View logs
docker-compose logs -f

# Reset data
docker-compose down -v
```

## ğŸƒâ€â™‚ï¸ Running the System

1. **Start Infrastructure**: `docker-compose up -d`
2. **Build Rust Components**: `cargo build --workspace`
3. **Setup Python Environment**: `cd python-backtester && ./setup_env.sh`
4. **Run Tests**: `cargo test --workspace && pytest`

## ğŸ“š Documentation

- [Architecture Documentation](docs/architecture/)
- [API Specifications](docs/prd/)
- [Development Workflow](docs/architecture/development-workflow.md)

## ğŸ¤ Contributing

1. Follow the established code style (rustfmt for Rust, black for Python)
2. Write tests for new functionality
3. Update documentation as needed
4. Run the full test suite before submitting

## ğŸ“„ License

MIT License - see LICENSE file for details

---

**Note**: This is a development version. Please refer to the documentation for production deployment guidelines.

file.content:
version: '3.8'

services:
  # ClickHouse - Time-series database for market data
  clickhouse:
    image: clickhouse/clickhouse-server:23.8
    container_name: trading_clickhouse
    hostname: clickhouse
    ports:
      - "8123:8123"    # HTTP interface
      - "9000:9000"    # Native client port
    volumes:
      - clickhouse_data:/var/lib/clickhouse
      - ./infrastructure/clickhouse/config.xml:/etc/clickhouse-server/config.xml:ro
      - ./infrastructure/clickhouse/users.xml:/etc/clickhouse-server/users.xml:ro
    environment:
      CLICKHOUSE_DB: trading_data
      CLICKHOUSE_USER: trading_user
      CLICKHOUSE_PASSWORD: ${CLICKHOUSE_PASSWORD:-trading_pass}
      CLICKHOUSE_DEFAULT_ACCESS_MANAGEMENT: 1
    networks:
      - trading_network
    restart: unless-stopped
    healthcheck:
      test: ["CMD", "clickhouse-client", "--query", "SELECT 1"]
      interval: 30s
      timeout: 10s
      retries: 3

  # Redis - High-speed caching and real-time data
  redis:
    image: redis:7.2-alpine
    container_name: trading_redis
    hostname: redis
    ports:
      - "6379:6379"
    volumes:
      - redis_data:/data
      - ./infrastructure/redis/redis.conf:/usr/local/etc/redis/redis.conf:ro
    command: redis-server /usr/local/etc/redis/redis.conf
    environment:
      REDIS_PASSWORD: ${REDIS_PASSWORD:-redis_pass}
    networks:
      - trading_network
    restart: unless-stopped
    healthcheck:
      test: ["CMD", "redis-cli", "ping"]
      interval: 30s
      timeout: 10s
      retries: 3

  # Zookeeper - Required for Kafka
  zookeeper:
    image: confluentinc/cp-zookeeper:7.4.0
    container_name: trading_zookeeper
    hostname: zookeeper
    ports:
      - "2181:2181"
    environment:
      ZOOKEEPER_CLIENT_PORT: 2181
      ZOOKEEPER_TICK_TIME: 2000
    volumes:
      - zookeeper_data:/var/lib/zookeeper/data
      - zookeeper_logs:/var/lib/zookeeper/log
    networks:
      - trading_network
    restart: unless-stopped
    healthcheck:
      test: ["CMD", "bash", "-c", "echo 'ruok' | nc localhost 2181"]
      interval: 30s
      timeout: 10s
      retries: 3

  # Kafka - Message streaming for market data
  kafka:
    image: confluentinc/cp-kafka:7.4.0
    container_name: trading_kafka
    hostname: kafka
    ports:
      - "9092:9092"
      - "9094:9094"
    depends_on:
      - zookeeper
    environment:
      KAFKA_BROKER_ID: 1
      KAFKA_ZOOKEEPER_CONNECT: zookeeper:2181
      KAFKA_LISTENER_SECURITY_PROTOCOL_MAP: PLAINTEXT:PLAINTEXT,PLAINTEXT_HOST:PLAINTEXT
      KAFKA_ADVERTISED_LISTENERS: PLAINTEXT://kafka:29092,PLAINTEXT_HOST://localhost:9092
      KAFKA_INTER_BROKER_LISTENER_NAME: PLAINTEXT
      KAFKA_OFFSETS_TOPIC_REPLICATION_FACTOR: 1
      KAFKA_TRANSACTION_STATE_LOG_MIN_ISR: 1
      KAFKA_TRANSACTION_STATE_LOG_REPLICATION_FACTOR: 1
      KAFKA_AUTO_CREATE_TOPICS_ENABLE: 'true'
      KAFKA_DELETE_TOPIC_ENABLE: 'true'
      KAFKA_LOG_RETENTION_HOURS: 24
      KAFKA_LOG_RETENTION_BYTES: 1073741824
      KAFKA_LOG_SEGMENT_BYTES: 268435456
    volumes:
      - kafka_data:/var/lib/kafka/data
    networks:
      - trading_network
    restart: unless-stopped
    healthcheck:
      test: ["CMD", "kafka-broker-api-versions", "--bootstrap-server=localhost:9092"]
      interval: 30s
      timeout: 10s
      retries: 3

  # Kafka UI - Web interface for Kafka management (development only)
  kafka-ui:
    image: provectuslabs/kafka-ui:latest
    container_name: trading_kafka_ui
    ports:
      - "8080:8080"
    depends_on:
      - kafka
    environment:
      KAFKA_CLUSTERS_0_NAME: trading_cluster
      KAFKA_CLUSTERS_0_BOOTSTRAPSERVERS: kafka:29092
      KAFKA_CLUSTERS_0_ZOOKEEPER: zookeeper:2181
    networks:
      - trading_network
    restart: unless-stopped
    profiles: ["development"]

  # Trading Engine - Rust-based execution engine
  trading-engine:
    build:
      context: .
      dockerfile: infrastructure/docker/Dockerfile.rust
    container_name: trading_engine
    hostname: trading-engine
    ports:
      - "50051:50051"  # gRPC port
    depends_on:
      - clickhouse
      - redis
      - kafka
    environment:
      RUST_LOG: info
      DATABASE_URL: clickhouse://trading_user:${CLICKHOUSE_PASSWORD:-trading_pass}@clickhouse:9000/trading_data
      REDIS_URL: redis://:${REDIS_PASSWORD:-redis_pass}@redis:6379
      KAFKA_BROKERS: kafka:29092
    volumes:
      - ./shared-config:/app/config:ro
    networks:
      - trading_network
    restart: unless-stopped
    profiles: ["application"]

  # Python Backtester - Analysis and backtesting service
  python-backtester:
    build:
      context: .
      dockerfile: infrastructure/docker/Dockerfile.python
    container_name: python_backtester
    hostname: python-backtester
    ports:
      - "8000:8000"   # FastAPI port
    depends_on:
      - clickhouse
      - redis
      - kafka
    environment:
      PYTHONPATH: /app
      DATABASE_URL: clickhouse://trading_user:${CLICKHOUSE_PASSWORD:-trading_pass}@clickhouse:8123/trading_data
      REDIS_URL: redis://:${REDIS_PASSWORD:-redis_pass}@redis:6379
      KAFKA_BROKERS: kafka:29092
    volumes:
      - ./shared-config:/app/config:ro
      - ./python-backtester:/app:ro
    networks:
      - trading_network
    restart: unless-stopped
    profiles: ["application"]

networks:
  trading_network:
    driver: bridge
    name: trading_network

volumes:
  clickhouse_data:
    name: trading_clickhouse_data
  redis_data:
    name: trading_redis_data
  zookeeper_data:
    name: trading_zookeeper_data
  zookeeper_logs:
    name: trading_zookeeper_logs
  kafka_data:
    name: trading_kafka_data

warn_unreachable = true
strict_equality = true

#!/bin/bash

# Virtual Environment Setup Script for Python Backtester
# This script sets up the Python virtual environment and installs dependencies

set -e

echo "Setting up Python virtual environment for backtester..."

# Check if Python 3.11+ is available
python_version=$(python3 --version 2>&1 | cut -d' ' -f2 | cut -d'.' -f1-2)
required_version="3.11"

if [ "$(printf '%s\n' "$required_version" "$python_version" | sort -V | head -n1)" != "$required_version" ]; then
    echo "Error: Python 3.11+ is required. Found Python $python_version"
    exit 1
fi

echo "âœ“ Python $python_version found"

# Navigate to python-backtester directory
cd "$(dirname "$0")"

# Create virtual environment if it doesn't exist
if [ ! -d "venv" ]; then
    echo "Creating virtual environment..."
    python3 -m venv venv
    echo "âœ“ Virtual environment created"
else
    echo "âœ“ Virtual environment already exists"
fi

# Activate virtual environment
echo "Activating virtual environment..."
source venv/bin/activate

# Upgrade pip
echo "Upgrading pip..."
pip install --upgrade pip

# Install dependencies
if [ -f "pyproject.toml" ]; then
    echo "Installing dependencies with Poetry..."
    pip install poetry
    poetry install
    echo "âœ“ Dependencies installed with Poetry"
elif [ -f "requirements.txt" ]; then
    echo "Installing dependencies from requirements.txt..."
    pip install -r requirements.txt
    echo "âœ“ Dependencies installed from requirements.txt"
else
    echo "Warning: No pyproject.toml or requirements.txt found"
fi

echo ""
echo "ğŸ‰ Python environment setup complete!"
echo ""
echo "To activate the environment, run:"
echo "  cd python-backtester && source venv/bin/activate"
echo ""
echo "To deactivate the environment, run:"
echo "  deactivate"

# Quantitative Trading Bot

A high-performance quantitative trading system built with Rust and Python, designed for real-time market data processing, algorithmic trading execution, and comprehensive backtesting analysis.

## ğŸ¯ Project Overview

This project implements a sophisticated trading system that combines:
- **Ultra-low latency trading execution** (Rust)
- **Advanced backtesting and analysis** (Python)
- **Real-time market data processing**
- **Comprehensive risk management**
- **Microservices architecture**

## ğŸ—ï¸ Monorepo Structure

```
quantitative-trading-bot/
â”œâ”€â”€ rust-engine/           # Rust trading execution services
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ trading-core/      # Core trading logic and execution
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ market-data/       # Market data ingestion and processing
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ risk-management/   # Real-time risk control systems
â”œâ”€â”€ python-backtester/     # Python backtesting and analysis
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ strategy-engine/   # Strategy development framework
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ data-analysis/     # Historical data analysis tools
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ reporting/         # Performance reporting and visualization
â”œâ”€â”€ shared-config/         # Shared configuration and schemas
â”œâ”€â”€ cli-interface/         # Terminal control interface
â”œâ”€â”€ infrastructure/        # Docker, K8s, and deployment configs
â””â”€â”€ docs/                  # Documentation and specifications
```

### Directory Purposes

- **`rust-engine/`**: High-performance trading execution components written in Rust for ultra-low latency
- **`python-backtester/`**: Python-based backtesting, analysis, and strategy development tools
- **`shared-config/`**: Common configuration files, schemas, and interfaces used across services
- **`cli-interface/`**: Command-line interface for system control and monitoring
- **`infrastructure/`**: Docker containers, Kubernetes manifests, and deployment configurations
- **`docs/`**: Project documentation, API specifications, and architectural decisions

## ğŸš€ Quick Start Guide

### Prerequisites

- **Rust 1.75+**
- **Python 3.11+**
- **Docker 24.0+**
- **Docker Compose**

### 1. Clone and Setup

```bash
git clone <repository-url>
cd quantitative-trading-bot
```

### 2. Setup Development Environment

#### Start Infrastructure Services
```bash
docker-compose up -d
```

#### Setup Rust Environment
```bash
# Build all Rust components
cargo build --workspace

# Run tests
cargo test --workspace

# Run benchmarks
cargo bench --workspace
```

#### Setup Python Environment
```bash
cd python-backtester
./setup_env.sh

# Activate virtual environment
source venv/bin/activate

# Install dependencies
poetry install
```

### 3. Verify Installation

```bash
# Test Rust components
cargo test --workspace

# Test Python components
cd python-backtester
pytest
```

## ğŸ› ï¸ Development Environment Setup

### Rust Development
- All Rust code is organized as a Cargo workspace
- Use `cargo build --workspace` to build all components
- Individual components can be built with `cargo build -p <package-name>`
- Benchmarks available with `cargo bench --workspace`

### Python Development
- Poetry is used for dependency management
- Virtual environment setup via `setup_env.sh` script
- Use `pytest` for running tests
- Code formatting with `black` and `isort`
- Type checking with `mypy`

### Infrastructure Services
The system requires several infrastructure components:
- **ClickHouse**: Time-series data storage
- **Redis**: High-speed caching
- **Kafka**: Market data streaming

Start all services with:
```bash
docker-compose up -d
```

## ğŸ”§ Technology Stack

| Component | Technology | Version | Purpose |
|-----------|------------|---------|---------|
| **Trading Engine** | Rust | 1.75+ | Ultra-low latency execution |
| **Backtesting** | Python | 3.11+ | Analysis and strategy development |
| **Async Runtime** | Tokio | 1.35+ | High-concurrency operations |
| **Web Framework** | FastAPI | 0.104+ | Python API services |
| **Time-Series DB** | ClickHouse | 23.8+ | Market data storage |
| **Cache** | Redis | 7.2+ | Real-time data caching |
| **Message Queue** | Kafka | 3.6+ | Event streaming |
| **Communication** | gRPC | 1.59+ | Inter-service communication |
| **Containerization** | Docker | 24.0+ | Application packaging |
| **Orchestration** | Kubernetes | 1.28+ | Production deployment |

## ğŸ“‹ Available Commands

### Rust Commands
```bash
# Build workspace
cargo build --workspace

# Run tests
cargo test --workspace

# Run benchmarks
cargo bench --workspace

# Check formatting
cargo fmt --check

# Run clippy lints
cargo clippy --workspace
```

### Python Commands
```bash
# Install dependencies
poetry install

# Run tests
pytest

# Run with coverage
pytest --cov=.

# Format code
black .
isort .

# Type checking
mypy .
```

### Infrastructure Commands
```bash
# Start services
docker-compose up -d

# Stop services
docker-compose down

# View logs
docker-compose logs -f

# Reset data
docker-compose down -v
```

## ğŸƒâ€â™‚ï¸ Running the System

1. **Start Infrastructure**: `docker-compose up -d`
2. **Build Rust Components**: `cargo build --workspace`
3. **Setup Python Environment**: `cd python-backtester && ./setup_env.sh`
4. **Run Tests**: `cargo test --workspace && pytest`

## ğŸ“š Documentation

- [Architecture Documentation](docs/architecture/)
- [API Specifications](docs/prd/)
- [Development Workflow](docs/architecture/development-workflow.md)

## ğŸ¤ Contributing

1. Follow the established code style (rustfmt for Rust, black for Python)
2. Write tests for new functionality
3. Update documentation as needed
4. Run the full test suite before submitting

## ğŸ“„ License

MIT License - see LICENSE file for details

"""Test Python package structure without external dependencies"""

import sys
import os

# Add current directory to path
sys.path.insert(0, os.path.dirname(os.path.dirname(__file__)))

def test_package_structure():
    """Test that all package directories and core files exist."""
    base_dir = os.path.dirname(os.path.dirname(__file__))
    
    # Check package directories
    packages = ['strategy_engine', 'data_analysis', 'reporting']
    for package in packages:
        package_dir = os.path.join(base_dir, package)
        assert os.path.isdir(package_dir), f"Package directory {package} not found"
        
        init_file = os.path.join(package_dir, '__init__.py')
        assert os.path.isfile(init_file), f"__init__.py not found in {package}"
        
    print("âœ… All package directories and __init__.py files exist")

def test_module_files():
    """Test that core module files exist."""
    base_dir = os.path.dirname(os.path.dirname(__file__))
    
    expected_files = {
        'strategy_engine': ['strategy.py', 'backtest.py'],
        'data_analysis': ['analyzer.py', 'indicators.py'],
        'reporting': ['metrics.py', 'generator.py']
    }
    
    for package, files in expected_files.items():
        for file in files:
            file_path = os.path.join(base_dir, package, file)
            assert os.path.isfile(file_path), f"Module file {package}/{file} not found"
            
    print("âœ… All expected module files exist")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    test_package_structure()
    test_module_files()
    print("ğŸ‰ All Python package structure tests passed!")

## Dev Agent Record

### Agent Model Used
Claude Sonnet 4 (claude-sonnet-4-20250514)

### Debug Log References
- Initial monorepo structure creation and validation
- Rust workspace configuration with proper dependency management 
- Python package structure setup with Poetry configuration
- Directory naming convention fix (hyphens to underscores for Python imports)
- Comprehensive testing of both Rust and Python components

### Completion Notes List
1. **Monorepo Structure**: Successfully created all required directories and subdirectories
2. **Rust Workspace**: Configured workspace with proper Cargo.toml files and basic module structure
3. **Python Environment**: Set up Poetry-managed environment with proper package structure
4. **Directory Naming Fix**: Corrected Python package names from hyphens to underscores for proper imports
5. **Configuration Files**: Enhanced .gitignore with trading-specific patterns, verified comprehensive README.md and docker-compose.yml
6. **Testing Infrastructure**: Created basic test structure and validation for both ecosystems

### File List
**Created/Modified Files:**
- `rust-engine/trading-core/src/lib.rs` - Core trading library with basic module structure
- `rust-engine/trading-core/src/{order,execution,portfolio}.rs` - Trading core modules
- `rust-engine/market-data/src/lib.rs` - Market data library with feed management
- `rust-engine/market-data/src/{feed,storage,websocket}.rs` - Market data modules  
- `rust-engine/risk-management/src/lib.rs` - Risk management library
- `rust-engine/risk-management/src/{position,limits,monitoring}.rs` - Risk modules
- `rust-engine/*/benches/*.rs` - Benchmark files for each Rust crate
- `python-backtester/strategy_engine/__init__.py` - Strategy engine package initialization
- `python-backtester/strategy_engine/{strategy,backtest}.py` - Strategy framework modules
- `python-backtester/data_analysis/__init__.py` - Data analysis package initialization  
- `python-backtester/data_analysis/{analyzer,indicators}.py` - Analysis and indicator modules
- `python-backtester/reporting/__init__.py` - Reporting package initialization
- `python-backtester/reporting/{metrics,generator}.py` - Performance reporting modules
- `python-backtester/tests/test_structure.py` - Python package structure validation tests
- `.gitignore` - Enhanced with trading-specific exclusion patterns
- `README.md` - Updated directory structure documentation

**Existing Files Verified:**
- `Cargo.toml` - Root workspace configuration (already properly configured)
- `python-backtester/pyproject.toml` - Poetry configuration (already comprehensive)
- `python-backtester/requirements.txt` - Python dependencies (already complete)
- `python-backtester/setup_env.sh` - Environment setup script (already functional)
- `docker-compose.yml` - Infrastructure services configuration (already comprehensive)
- `.env.example` - Environment variables template (already complete)
